paragraphs.text:
// easy enough to query flat JSON
    val people = sqlContext.read.json("/resources/Datasets/flatpeople.json")
    people.printSchema()
    people.registerTempTable("people")
    people.show()
    
    val young = sqlContext.sql("SELECT firstName, lastName FROM people WHERE age < 30")
    young.show()

paragraphs.text:
%sh
echo "flatpeople"
cat /resources/Datasets/flatpeople.json
printf "\nnonflatpeople\n"
cat /resources/Datasets/nonflatpeople.json
printf "\nnonflatbadpeople - has an extra $ sysmbol on the state variable\n"
cat /resources/Datasets/nonflatbadpeople.json
printf "\nmixed.json\n"
cat /resources/Datasets/mixed.json
printf "\npeople.txt\n"
cat /resources/Datasets/people.txt

// nested JSON results in fields that have compound names, like address.state
    val peopleAddr = sqlContext.read.json("/resources/Datasets/nonflatpeople.json")
    peopleAddr.printSchema()
    peopleAddr.show()
    peopleAddr.registerTempTable("peopleAddr")
    val inPA = sqlContext.sql("SELECT firstName, lastName FROM peopleAddr WHERE address.state = 'PA'")
    inPA.show()

paragraphs.text:
// interesting characters in field names lead to problems with querying, as Spark SQL
    // has no quoting mechanism for identifiers
    val peopleAddrBad = sqlContext.read.json("/resources/Datasets/nonflatbadpeople.json")
    peopleAddrBad.printSchema()
    peopleAddrBad.collect.foreach(println)
    
    // instead read the JSON in as an RDD[String], do necessary string
    // manipulations (example below is simplistic) and then turn it into a Schema RDD
    val lines = sc.textFile("/resources/Datasets/nonflatbadpeople.json")
    val linesFixed = lines.map(s => s.replaceAllLiterally("$", ""))
    val peopleAddrFixed = sqlContext.read.json(linesFixed)
    peopleAddrFixed.printSchema()
    peopleAddrFixed.registerTempTable("peopleAddrFixed")
    peopleAddrFixed.show()
    val inPAFixed = sqlContext.sql("SELECT firstName, lastName FROM peopleAddrFixed WHERE address.state = 'PA'")
    inPAFixed.show()

paragraphs.text:
/*
mixed.json
{ "a": 1, "id": "101", "since": "2001", "orders":[ {"oid":"100001"} ] }
{ "id": "102", "a": 2, "address":{"zip": "98016"}, "since": 1999 }
{ "a": 3.1, "id": "103", "since": "foo", "orders":[ {"oid":"300001", "SKU":"B001"}, {"oid":"300002", "SKU":"B005"}, {"oid":"300003", "SKU":"A007"} ] }
*/
    val transactions = sqlContext.read.json("/resources/Datasets/mixed.json")
    transactions.printSchema()
    transactions.registerTempTable("transactions")


    val all = sqlContext.sql("SELECT id FROM transactions")
    all.show()

    val more = sqlContext.sql("SELECT id, since FROM transactions")
    more.show()

    val deeper = sqlContext.sql("SELECT id, address.zip FROM transactions")
    deeper.show()

    println("selecting an array valued column")
    val array1 = sqlContext.sql("SELECT id, orders FROM transactions")
    array1.show()

    println("selecting a specific array element")
    val array2 = sqlContext.sql("SELECT id, orders[0] FROM transactions")
    array2.show()

// easy enough to query flat JSON
    val people = sqlContext.read.json("/resources/Datasets/flatpeople.json")
    val strings =  OutputJSON.formatDataFrame(people.schema, people)
    strings.collect.foreach(println)
    println()

    val peopleAddr = sqlContext.read.json("/resources/Datasets/nonflatpeople.json")
    val nestedStrings = OutputJSON.formatDataFrame(peopleAddr.schema, peopleAddr)
    nestedStrings.collect.foreach(println)
    nestedStrings.toDebugString
    nestedStrings.collect
    //nestedStrings.take(3)

paragraphs.text:
import org.apache.commons.io.IOUtils
import java.net.URL
import java.nio.charset.Charset

// Zeppelin creates and injects sc (SparkContext) and sqlContext (HiveContext or SqlContext)
// So you don't need create them manually

// load bank data
val bankText = sc.parallelize(
    IOUtils.toString(
        new URL("https://s3.amazonaws.com/apache-zeppelin/tutorial/bank/bank.csv"),
        Charset.forName("utf8")).split("\n"))

case class Bank(age: Integer, job: String, marital: String, education: String, balance: Integer)

bankText.take(5).foreach(println)

paragraphs.text:
import org.apache.spark.sql.functions._
//Let's start off by looking at all rides under 2 hours.
    sqlContext.sql("SELECT Duration as d1 from bay_area_bike where Duration < 7200").limit(10).show()

    sqlContext.setConf("spark.sql.retainGroupColumns", "true")
    println("*** Column based aggregation")

    
    val dep_stations = bay_area_bike.groupBy("Start Station").agg(max($"Duration"),min($"Duration"),avg($"Duration"),count($"Zip Code"))
    dep_stations.limit(10).show()
    
    val dep_stations = bay_area_bike.groupBy("Start Station").agg(max($"Duration"),min($"Duration"),avg($"Duration"),count($"Zip Code"))
    dep_stations.limit(10).show()

/*

root
 |-- Bike #: string (nullable = true)
 |-- End Date: string (nullable = true)
 |-- End Station: string (nullable = true)
 |-- End Terminal: string (nullable = true)
 |-- Start Date: string (nullable = true)
 |-- Start Station: string (nullable = true)
 |-- Start Terminal: string (nullable = true)
 |-- Subscription Type: string (nullable = true)
 |-- Trip ID: string (nullable = true)
 |-- Zip Code: string (nullable = true)
 |-- Duration: integer (nullable = true)
 SELECT "Start Terminal", "Start Station", COUNT(1) AS count FROM bay_area_bike GROUP BY startterminal, startstation ORDER BY count DESC LIMIT 10
*/

val featureDf = bay_area_bike
    .withColumn("Bikeno", bay_area_bike("Bike #")).drop("Bike #")
    .withColumn("EndDate", bay_area_bike("End Date")).drop("End Date")
    .withColumn("EndStation", bay_area_bike("End Station")).drop("End Station")
    .withColumn("EndTerminal", bay_area_bike("End Terminal")).drop("End Terminal")
    .withColumn("StartDate", bay_area_bike("Start Date")).drop("Start Date")
    .withColumn("StartStation", bay_area_bike("Start Station")).drop("Start Station")
    .withColumn("StartTerminal", bay_area_bike("Start Terminal")).drop("Start Terminal")
    .withColumn("SubscriptionType", bay_area_bike("Subscription Type")).drop("Subscription Type")
    .withColumn("TripID", bay_area_bike("Trip ID")).drop("Trip ID")
    .withColumn("ZipCode", bay_area_bike("Zip Code")).drop("Zip Code")                        
    

featureDf.registerTempTable("bay_area_bike")
featureDf.printSchema()

%sql

--SELECT StartTerminal, StartStation FROM bay_area_bike
--Letâ€™s find the top 10 most popular start stations based on the trip data:	
SELECT StartTerminal, StartStation, COUNT(1) AS count FROM bay_area_bike GROUP BY StartTerminal, StartStation ORDER BY count DESC LIMIT 10

paragraphs.text:
%sql
SELECT
 s.id,
 s.stationName,
 s.latitude,
 s.longitude,
 COUNT(1) AS count
FROM bay_area_bike t
JOIN stations s ON s.id = t.EndTerminal
WHERE t.startterminal = 70
GROUP BY s.id, s.stationName, s.latitude, s.longitude
ORDER BY count DESC LIMIT 10

paragraphs.text:
%sql
SELECT
    hour,
    COUNT(1) AS bay_area_bike,
    ROUND(AVG(Duration) / 60) AS avg_duration
FROM (
    SELECT
        CAST(SPLIT(SPLIT(t.StartDate, ' ')[1], ':')[0] AS INT) AS hour,
        t.duration AS duration
    FROM bay_area_bike t
    WHERE
        t.StartTerminal = 70
        AND
        t.Duration IS NOT NULL
    ) r
GROUP BY hour
ORDER BY hour ASC

%pyspark

#Gracefully Dealing with Bad Input Data

import json
input_rdd = sc.parallelize(["{\"value\": 1}",  # Good
                            "bad_json",  # Bad
                            "{\"value\": 2}",  # Good
                            "{\"value\": 3"  # Missing an ending brace.
                            ])
def try_correct_json(json_string):
  try:
    # First check if the json is okay.
    json.loads(json_string)
    return [json_string]
  except ValueError:
    try:
      # If not, try correcting it by adding a ending brace.
      try_to_correct_json = json_string + "}"
      json.loads(try_to_correct_json)
      return [try_to_correct_json]
    except ValueError:
      # The malformed json input can't be recovered, drop this input.
      return []
      
corrected_input_rdd = input_rdd.flatMap(try_correct_json)
sqlContext.jsonRDD(corrected_input_rdd).registerTempTable("valueTable")
print sqlContext.sql("select * from valueTable").collect()

result.msg: [Row(value=1), Row(value=2), Row(value=3)]

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

#https://pymotw.com/2/json/

import json

data = [ { 'a':'A', 'b':(2, 4), 'c':3.0 } ]
print 'DATA:', repr(data)

print 'NORMAL:', json.dumps(data, sort_keys=True)
print 'INDENT:', json.dumps(data, sort_keys=True, indent=2)


unsorted = json.dumps(data)
print 'JSON:', json.dumps(data)
print 'SORT:', json.dumps(data, sort_keys=True)

first = json.dumps(data, sort_keys=True)
second = json.dumps(data, sort_keys=True)

print 'UNSORTED MATCH:', unsorted == first
print 'SORTED MATCH  :', first == second

print 'repr(data)             :', len(repr(data))
print 'dumps(data)            :', len(json.dumps(data))
print 'dumps(data, indent=2)  :', len(json.dumps(data, indent=2))
print 'dumps(data, separators):', len(json.dumps(data, separators=(',',':')))

data = [ { 'a':'A', 'b':(2, 4), 'c':3.0, ('d',):'D tuple' } ]

print 'First attempt'
try:
    print json.dumps(data)
except (TypeError, ValueError) as err:
    print 'ERROR:', err

print
print 'Second attempt'
print json.dumps(data, skipkeys=True)

from urllib import urlopen
#import simplejson as json

url = urlopen("http://21.luckyminers.com/index.php?page=api&action=getpoolstatus&api_key=8dba7050f9fea1e6a554bbcf4c3de5096795b253b45525c53562b72938771c41").read()
print url
#url = json.loads(url)
#print url.get('getpoolstatus').get('data').get('networkdiff')
